It seems that most people who join this community were looking for a Drupal alternative. Although googling for "drupal alternatives" does not mention Backdrop at all (at least here in Central Europe, German search settings... could be quite different in other locations). I really guess this could be our lowest hanging fruit at all: make Backdrop appear when entering "Drupal Alternatives")

Screenshot-2020-05-20-at-10.06.14.png Screenshot-2020-05-20-at-10.05.15.png

On the other hand, I still got good traffic for "Drupal Alternative" (non-plural) for my german blog post here, who really is targeted at people with good D7 knowledge. https://mazze.ch/backdropcms

So... translating the article and tweaking the H1 might bring really good high quality traffic. I could write an update 2020 version, but really need some help with proofreading in English. I will bring this up at outreach meeting, OK?

Von Drupal zu Backdrop CMS
Backdrop CMS ist ein sogenannter «Fork» von Drupal. Solche Abspaltungen vom «Mutterprojekt» sind ein wichtiger Kern der Opensource-Idee, aber in der Praxis meistens von erheblichen Nebengeräuschen begleitet. Das war vor über fünf Jahren im Drupal-Projekt nicht anders. Eine Gruppe um Jen Lampton und Nate Haug – beides langjährige Drupal-Entwickler – kündigte an, eine frühe Version von Drupal 8 zu «forken» und fortan eigenständig weiterzuentwickeln. Warum es Backdrop CMS überhaupt gibt Was war passiert?

With the updates to ubercart, I like Backdrop for eCommerce sites!! We already have 2 up and running, and hopefully more to come. I have one big catalog site on D7 I'm planning on converting in the next couple of years (when I can convince them to spend the money). Backdrop will really be the easiest and cheapest way for them to go.
@Elisabeth Garbeil an explanation of your use cases, relative size of custom coding will be very interesting. Thank you!

Vladimir said:

Elisabeth Garbeil an explanation of your use cases, relative size of custom coding will be very interesting. Thank you!

@Vladimir
I don't do much in the way of custom coding, other than themes - which are ALL custom child themes of basic or corporate KISS. Those are very heavily customized per client. I may port modules as I need or take an existing module and customize to meet a use case, but I do that sparingly. I don't have the time with over 100 clients, and my client base will pay for custom theming but not coding as a rule (they can't see it, they don't want to pay for it.)
The few cases of custom coding I have needed on Backdrop so far are:
1) Adding IMCE to link dialog (still working on this one and when it's ready will submit for contrib)
2) Adding buttons to ckeditor for editing such as indent and outdent (this is now a contrib module - not mine)
3) Adding IMCE file editor to image field (this is a forthcoming need for the catalog client )

Use Cases (just a few examples)
1) NSFW - adult toy shop https://sensualwhipsandtoys.com. This site really made use of ubercart attributes. This would have been an absolute nightmare to set up and for the client to maintain in Commerce. I had a client years ago on Commerce (Custom t-shirt shop) that had to shut down their site because the time required to keep the site updated was too much for them. Ubercart couldn't handle their requirements at the time.

2) Catholic high school - eCommerce is used for event ticketing, transcript fees, and so on. https://mhsmi.org. (We have more that will have to be migrated eventually as well, but pretty much the same functions.)
3) Office Furniture Site - this is a catalog site that has their inventory online but not does not purchase online (the product costs too much to ship). It's an eCommerce site with no payment, but webform blocks with every item, so that will be a bit of custom.
4) Parts manufacturer - this will be a custom eCommerce solution using Ubercart. The custom portion will be filter view blocks on side that allow narrowing of product choices (think Amazon or Best Buy). I scoped it out years ago for them in D7 and am now expecting that I will need to do it in Backdrop, but the scoping I did should work for D7 as well. I may have to port Better Exposed Filters for this, but who knows by the time they're ready to spend the money to move.
5) I have 4 eCommerce clients on CubeCart / Open Cart that I don't' think will ever move. I'd love to get them on Backdrop, but I don't think it will ever happen, due to the expense.

Hope that helps!
